facts.text: Appeal is Civil Appeal No. 219 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 219 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated August 31, 1960 of Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Decree No. 7 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated August 31, 1960 of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original decree No. 7 of 1955.

facts.text: Respondents owned 0.12 acre of land in village Bermo No. 18 in district of Hazaribagh.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents owned an area of 0.12 acre of land in village Bermo No. 18 in the district of Hazaribagh.

facts.text: Land required for construction of Aerial Rope-way for Bokaro Thermal Power Plant.

anchor.surface_text: This land was required for the companystruction of Aerial Rope-way for Bokaro Thermal Power Plant, and so, in order to acquire the said land,

facts.text: Declaration under s. 4 of the Act made on August 9, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: a declaration under s. 4 of the Act was made on August 9, 1952.

facts.text: Property consists of two buildings: main structure and out-houses with open space in front.

anchor.surface_text: The property of the respondents which stands on this plot companysists of two buildings, one is the main structure and the other is made up of out-houses together with an open space of land in front of these structures.

facts.text: Government thought it necessary to acquire 50 ft width for electric wire including portion of open space and out-houses.

anchor.surface_text: The numberification showed that the Government thought it necessary, to acquire a space of 50 fit in width for the electric wire to run over and this included a portion of open space as also the out-houses of the respondents.

facts.text: Land Acquisition Officer fixed compensation at Rs. 4,451/5/6 for land and out-houses.

anchor.surface_text: Under the proceedings taken under the relevant provisions of the Act, the Land Acquisition Officer fixed the companypensation to be paid to the respondents at Rs. 4,4511516

facts.text: Land Acquisition Officer made award on November 27, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: after the date of the numberification and before the award was made on November 27, 1952.

facts.text: Respondents not satisfied with award and applied for reference under s. 18.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents were number satisfied with this award, and so, they applied for reference under s. 18 of the Act.

facts.text: In para 1(d) of reference petition, respondents claimed other contiguous lands and buildings not acquired causing huge loss, entitled to Rs. 21,765/8/- construction cost and loss of Rs. 160/- monthly rent.

anchor.surface_text: One of the grounds taken by the respondents in para I  d  of their petition for reference was that the other lands and buildings companytiguous to the land and building acquired which belonged to them had number been acquired, and in companysequence, they had to suffer a huge loss the rope-line passes close to the rest of the property, and so, it companyld number be used for fear of its being dangerous for human habitation. On this basis, the respondents alleged that they were entitled to recover as companypensation amount Rs. 21,765/8/- which they had spent on the companystruction of the principal building. Besides, they urged that the monthly rent of Rs. 160/- which they were receiving from the tenants in respect of the said principal building would also be lost

facts.text: Deputy Commissioner of Hazaribagh made the reference.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commissioner of Hazaribagh then proceeded to make the reference as claimed by the respondents.

facts.text: Kundan Singh, respondent No. 1, gave evidence before District Judge that on October 22, 1952, he applied for acquisition of other quarters as contiguous and useless.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that before the District judge, Kundan Singh, respondent No. 1, gave evidence and stated that on October 22, 1952, he-had put in an application that the other quarters belonging to him which had number been acquired should also be acquired, because the said quarters were companytiguous to the land acquired and had become useless to the respondents.

facts.text: District Judge of Hazaribagh awarded Rs. 4,451/5/6 plus additional Rs. 1,000/- for injury to unacquired property.

anchor.surface_text: the learned District judge companysidered the point raised by the respondents and held that since only a narrow strip of land had been left in front of the larger building, it had affected -the utility of the said building and the other unacquired land of the respondents, and so, he directed that in addition to the amount of Rs. 4 451/5/6 which had been determined as the amount of companypensation by the Land Acquisition Officer, Rs. 1000/- should be paid to the respondents.

facts.text: Respondents preferred appeal to Patna High Court under s. 54.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents then preferred an appeal before the High Court of Patna under s. 54 of the Act.

facts.text: In High Court appeal, respondents claimed Land Acquisition Officer should acquire main building as rope-way spoiled it.

anchor.surface_text: In their appeal, the only ground which they urged was that the rope-way having companypletely spoiled the main building, the Land Acquisition Officer companyld number acquire the out-houses without acquiring the main building.

facts.text: Appellants contended claim for acquisition of other properties not open in s.18 reference appeal, pertains to s.49, not raised before LAO or District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: When this plea was raised before the High Court, the appellants,-the State of Bihar and the Deputy Commissioner, Hazaribagh, companytended that it was number open to the respondents to claim a declaration for the acquisition of other properties in their appeal, because the said appeal arose out of a reference under s. 18 of the Act and a plea like the one raised by the respondents which companyld be made under s. 49 of the Act, was foreign to the present enquiry. It was also companytended that this point had number been taken by the respondents either before the Land Acquisition Officer or before the District judge.

facts.text: Patna High Court directed Land Acquisition Officer to acquire remaining area and building, assess compensation, deduct Rs.1,000/- previously awarded.

anchor.surface_text: These arguments were rejected by the High Court and a direction has been issued by the High Court calling upon the Land Acquisition Officer to takeover the remaining area and the building and assess the companypensation thereon in due companyrse according to law. The High Court has ordered that when the said assessment is thus determined, the additional companypensation of Rs. 1,000/which has been allowed by the District judge should be deducted

facts.text: Appellants appealed to Supreme Court with certificate from High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order that the appellants have companye to this Court with a certificate issued by the High Court

facts.text: District Judge did not accept plea of s.49 application by respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the District judge shows that he did number accept this plea, and so, he proceeded to deal with the case on the basis that the respondents were claiming additional companypensation either under the third or the fourth clause of s. 23  1  of the Act.

facts.text: No application under s.49 produced before High Court or Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: but it is remarkable that the said statement does number appear to have been pressed before the District judge and when it was attempted to be pressed before the High Court, the application alleged to have been made by respondent No. I was number produced before or shown to the High Court at all. In fact, numbersuch application has been printed in the paper- book prepared for this Court in the present appeal.

facts.text: Supreme Court held respondents did not make application under s.49 before award, claim was under s.23(1).

anchor.surface_text: We have already referred to the ground taken by the respondents in para I  d  of their petition and have numbericed that the claim made under the said ground was under s. 23 of the Act and number at all under s. 49 and so, we are number prepared to accept Mr. Iyengers argument that the present appeal should be dealt with on the basis that the respondents had made an application to the Land Acquisition Officer under s. 49 of the Act before he pronounced his award.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside High Court order, restored District Judge order.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal is allowed, the order passed by the High Court is set aside and that of the District judge restored.

issues.text: Whether the High Court was in error in allowing s. 49 to be invoked in the appeal before it under s. 54 from the reference under s. 18

anchor.surface_text: It is against this order that the appellants have come to this Court with a certificate issued by the High Court and the principal question which has been raised before us by Mr. Sen on behalf of the appellants is that the High Court was in error is allowing s. 49 to be invoked in the appeal before it.

issues.text: Whether the respondents had made an application to the Land Acquisition Officer under s. 49 of the Act before the award under s. 11

anchor.surface_text: The first point which must be considered in dealing with the appellants argument is whether the respondents had made an application to the Land Acquisition Officer under s. 49 of the Act as alleged by respondent No. I in his evidence before the District judge.

issues.text: Whether the High Court could have entertained the respondents' plea under s. 49 in the appeal under s. 54 preferred against the decision of the District Judge in reference proceedings under s. 18

anchor.surface_text: In the light of this finding that we have to determine the question as to whether the High Court could have entertained the respondents plea under s. 49 in the appeal preferred before it by the respondents against the decision of the District Judge in reference proceedings taken before him under s. 18 of the Act.

issues.text: Whether the scope of enquiry under s. 18(1) permits consideration of claims under s. 49

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it is very difficult to accede to Mr. Iyengers argument that in dealing with the reference proceedings under s. 18(1), the Court can also consider the pleas raised by the owner of the property under s. 49 of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: No application produced; para 1(d) under s.23 not s.49; s.18 scope does not permit s.49

arguments.claim: Scope of s.18(1) enquiry limited to measurement of land, amount of compensation, persons entitled, apportionment; cannot include s.49 pleas

anchor.surface_text: Section 18  1  provides that any person interested who has not accepted the award may, by written application to the Collector,require that the matter be referred by the Collector or the determination of the Court, whether his objection be to the measurement of the land, the amount of the compensation, the persons to whom it is payable, or the apportionment of the compensation among the persons interested.

arguments.claim: Under s.49(1), owner must express desire for whole house acquisition before Collector award under s.11; prohibition on partial acquisition if desire expressed timely

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of s. 49  1  prescribe, inter alia, a definite prohibition against putting in force any of the provisions of the Act for the purpose of acquiring a part only of any house, if the owner desires that the whole of such house shall be acquired.

arguments.claim: s.49 and s.18 are separate distinct proceedings; s.49 claim cannot be raised in s.18 reference

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it is very difficult to accede to Mr. Iyengers argument that in dealing with the reference proceedings under s. 18(1), the Court can also consider the pleas raised by the owner of the property under s. 49 of the Act.

arguments.claim: In Pramatha Nath Mullick, Privy Council held s.18 specifies four grounds only for reference

anchor.surface_text: As was observed by the Privy Council in Pramatha Nath Mullick Secretary of State for India , the section clearly specifies four different grounds of objection which can be the subject-matter of an enquiry in reference proceedings.

arguments.claim: No need to express s.49 desire at particular stage before award; special circumstances justify post-award claim

anchor.surface_text: In the Secretary of State for India in Council v. Narayanaswamy Chettier , the Madras High Court appears to have taken the view that there is nothing in s. 49 requiring the claimant to put forward his particular claim, viz., that the whole of his house should be acquired, at any particular stage of the proceedings.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: er companyrectly interpret the effect of s. 49  1  when it held that the said section did number require the claimant to put forward his claim before

arguments.court_reasoning: Scheme of s.49 requires before s.11 award; prohibition mandatory

arguments.claim: Owner must apply under s.49(1) before award actually made

anchor.surface_text: In Krishna Das Roy v. The Land Acquisition Collector of Pabna , the Calcutta High Court, on the other hand, seems to have taken the view and we think, rightly, that if the owner wants to make an application expressing his desire under s. 49  1 , he has to make that application some time before the award is actually made.

arguments.claim: Present acquisition attracts provisions of s.49(1) requiring whole property

holdings.text: The claim made by the respondents in para 1(d) of their s.18 petition was under s.23 of the Act and not at all under s.49.

anchor.surface_text: We have already referred to the ground taken by the respondents in para I d of their petition and have noticed that the claim made under the said ground was under s. 23 of the Act and not at all under s. 49

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analysis of para 1(d) text seeks compensation for loss to unacquired property due to proximity of ropeway, fitting s.23(1) third/fourth clauses, not desire for whole acquisition under s.49.

holdings.text: The respondents did not make an application under s.49 to the Land Acquisition Officer before he pronounced his award.

anchor.surface_text: and so, we are not prepared to accept Mr. Iyengar's argument that the present appeal should be dealt with on the basis that the respondents had made an application to the Land Acquisition Officer under s. 49 of the Act before he pronounced his award.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No application produced in evidence before District Judge, High Court or Supreme Court; District Judge rejected plea and treated as s.23 claim; respondent's evidence not pressed or accepted.

holdings.text: The scope of enquiry under s.18(1) is limited to objections on measurement of land, amount of compensation, persons entitled, or apportionment; does not permit consideration of claims under s.49.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, it is very difficult to accede to Mr. Iyengar's argument that in dealing with the reference proceedings under s. 18(1), the Court can also consider the pleas raised by the owner of the property under s. 49 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory text limits s.18(1) to four specific grounds; s.49 provides separate procedure; follows Privy Council in Pramatha Nath Mullick limiting reference to specified objections.

holdings.text: Under s.49(1), the owner must express desire for acquisition of the whole house or building before the Collector makes award under s.11.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, it would be seen that the scheme of s. 49 is that the owner has to express his desire that the whole of his house should be acquired before the award is made, and once such a desire is expressed,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s.49(1) prohibition and provisos requires timely objection post-ss.4/6 but pre-s.11 award to avoid complications; follows Calcutta HC in Krishna Das Roy, distinguishes Madras HC in Narayanaswamy on special facts.

holdings.text: s.49 claims cannot be raised in reference proceedings under s.18 or appeal therefrom under s.54; they are separate and distinct proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: This procedure is distinct and separate from the procedure which has to be followed in making a reference under s. 18 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.49 mandates specific pre-award procedure with possible court reference under its proviso; cannot mix with s.18 compensation/apportionment enquiry; harmonious construction of statutory scheme.

holdings.text: The High Court erred in entertaining and allowing the respondents' plea under s.49 in the appeal under s.54 from the s.18 reference.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, the High Court did not correctly interpret the effect of s. 49(1) when it held that the said section did not require the claimant to put forward his claim before the award was made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No pre-award s.49 application; plea outside s.18 scope; High Court misread s.49 timing requirement; appeal allowed, High Court order set aside, District Judge order restored.
